node.description: TTC control and monitoring. It takes care of locking to the TTC clock coming from the backplane as well as decoding TTC commands and forwarding that to all other modules in the design. It also provides several control and monitoring registers (resets, command decoding configuration, clock and data status, bc0 status, command counters and a small spy buffer)
Enable L1As (L1As are blocked if this is 0)
TTC configuration -- used for setup TTC command decoding
TTC stream single bit error count
TTC stream double bit error count
BX counter overflow count (late or no BC0 received)
BX counter underflow count (early BC0 received, one is normal after the TTC module reset, but this should be reset by control software before each run)
L1A ID (increments with every L1A and resets with EC0), used by DAQ to tag event numbers

TTC Spy buffer -- this is filled with TTC commands (from LSB to MSB) and freezes until the user reads it out, once read out it resets and fills up again with new TTC commands received from that point on
Trigger module handles everything related to sbit cluster data (link synchronization, monitoring, local triggering, matching to L1A and reporting data to DAQ)
OH trigger kill mask (kills all sbits from the corresponding OHs)
OR-Trigger rate (Hz) -- this trigger fires whenever there's at least one valid sbit cluster on any link
OR-Trigger count -- this trigger fires whenever there's at least one valid sbit cluster on any link
Trigger rate (Hz) -- this trigger fires whenever there's at least one valid sbit cluster
Trigger count -- this trigger fires whenever there's at least one valid sbit cluster
Rate of cluster size ${CS_IDX} (size 0 means no sbit clusters)
Count of cluster size ${CS_IDX} (size 0 means no sbit clusters)
Count of valid flag being 0 in the sync FIFO for link 0
Count of valid flag being 0 in the sync FIFO for link 1
Count of missed comma character at the expected time for link 0 (this indicates an out-of-sync condition)
Count of missed comma character at the expected time for link 1 (this indicates an out-of-sync condition)
Count of overflow occurances in the sync FIFO for link 0
Count of overflow occurances in the sync FIFO for link 1
Count of underflow occurances in the sync FIFO for link 0
Count of underflow occurances in the sync FIFO for link 1
Count of sync words seen on link 0
Count of sync words seen on link 1
This module is controlling GEM AMC System wide settings
RX polarity of the track/control links (bit 0 corresponds to link 0)
TX polarity of the track/control links (bit 0 corresponds to link 0)
Board ID that gets embedded in the AMC13 header
Legacy system registers (taken from GLIB system core). These should be removed once the software is made compatible with the new system registers.
DAQ module buffers track data, builds events, analyses the data for consistency and ships off the events with all the needed headers and trailers to AMC13 over DAQLink
If this is set to 0, there will be no data sent to AMC13 and TTS state will always be READY (0x8)

Directly connected to DAQLink module reset port. BU is advising against ever using it except for powerup, but it may clear some error conditions (like daqlink_almost_ful stuck at 1). AMC13 reset is probably required after this.

Clears all FIFOs, state flags and counters. It also stops and resets all state machines (no events will be built, recorded or sent during reset) When set to 1, it will be held in reset state until 0 is explicitly written (this can be changed in the future if necessary)
When not 0, it will override the GLIB TTS state with the provided value (e.g. writing 0x8 will force GLIB to always be in TTS READY state)
This is a bitmask telling GLIB to enable certain inputs (least significant bit is input 0). Only first is enabled by default

This setting controls how long DAQ will wait for individual inputs to report data before calling it timed-out (if timeout occurs a header and trailer for that chamber will still be inserted and timeout flag will be set there, though no VFAT payload will be present). Units = clock cycles @ 25MHz (current DAQLink clk frequency)
When this is 1, it means that GLIB is in good communication with AMC13. It must be 1 for GLIB to be able to send data.
This flag is 1 if DAQ clock is locked at this moment
This flag is 1 if TTC clock MMCM is locked

This bit comes directly from DAQLink module, indicating that its internal buffers are almost full. No events will be sent when this bit is 1 (though events can still be built and stored in the Input and Event FIFOs)
This bit is set if DAQ output FIFO has ever been full (critical -- data loss)
This bit is set if BC0 is currently locked (last BC0 arrived at the expected time)
This bit is latched whenever L1A FIFO overflow is asserted. This means that one or more L1As were lost, so we are out-of-sync: resync or reset is needed
L1A FIFO is in underflow at this moment (this bit is not latched)
L1A FIFO is full at this moment (this bit is not latched)
This bit gets asserted when L1A FIFO gets 75% full and deasserted when it gets down to 50%
L1A FIFO is empty at this moment (this bit is not latched)
Current TTS state (READY, BUSY, ERROR, WARN, OUT-OF-SYNC)
This counter is counting DAQLink GTX/GTH not-in-table errors
This counter is counting DAQLink GTX/GTH dispersion errors
Current L1A ID (similar to event number, but this may be a bit ahead of that if we're still waiting for data for unprocessed L1As)
Number of events shipped out to DAQLink

This indicates the maximum amount of time that DAQ had to wait for all inputs to report data (can be used to optimize DAV timeout setting). Units = clock cycles @ DAQ clock frequency (currently using 40.08MHz TTC clock) (current DAQLink clk frequency)
This indicates how DAQ had to wait for all inputs to report data for the last event (mostly for debugging). Units = clock cycles @ DAQ clock frequency (currently using 40.08MHz TTC clock)
User settable run type that gets embedded into the AMC header
User settable run params that gets embedded into the AMC header

Units = clock cycles @ 160MHz. If no new data was received in this amount of time, GLIB will close the current event and report it to DAQ. This is one of the two ways to close an event, the other is to get new data with different BX number
There was at least one event with mixed VFAT Event IDs
There was at least one event with mixed VFAT BX IDs
There was at least one event with mixed OH BX IDs (OH BX ID is reported for every VFAT block, but not sent to AMC13).
Corruption: more than 24 VFATs in event

Corruption: VFAT marker not detected. There was at least one VFAT block not conforming to the pattern of Axxx Cxxx Exxx... (see VFAT data format) Note that this data will still be included in the current event and sent to AMC13, but it will not be considered in end­of­event detection
Critical: Input FIFO overflow occurred. This bit is latched if Input FIFO was ever full when receiving new data – this means data was lost. TTS ERROR is asserted when this bit is 1

Critical: Input FIFO underflow occurred. This bit is latched if Input FIFO underflow was ever detected. This means that Event FIFO indicated that there should be more data than was stored in Input FIFO. This might happen due to overflow or some other malfunction. TTS ERROR is asserted when this bit is 1

Critical: Event FIFO overflow occurred. This bit is latched if Event FIFO was ever full when trying to build a new event. This means data was lost. It’s not likely that this will ever be asserted because Input FIFO should overflow first. TTS ERROR is asserted when this bit is 1

Critical: Event size overflow occurred. This bit is latched if there was an event containing more than 4096 VFAT blocks. Input FIFO and Event FIFO will be out­of­sync. This might happen if end­of­event is not detected properly or for whatever reason GLIB is receiving a stream of VFAT blocks indicating that they belong to the same event (EC/BC is the same) TTS ERROR is asserted when this bit is 1
Input TTS state (gets integrated into global TTS state later)
Current status: Input FIFO is in underflow
Current status: Input FIFO is full
Current status: Input FIFO is near­full (asserted at 75% and deasserted at 50%)
Current status: Input FIFO is empty
Current status: Event FIFO is in underflow
Current status: Event FIFO is full
Current status: Event FIFO is near­full (asserted at 75% and deasserted at 50%)
Current status: Event FIFO is empty

This counter is incremented when a VFAT block does not conform to the pattern of Axxx Cxxx Exxx... (see VFAT data format) Note that this data is still included in events and sent to AMC13, but it does not participate in end-of-event detection.

Current event number of the event builder. This counter starts at 1 and increments with each end-of-event detection. This number should be similar to the number of events sent to AMC13 in normal operation, but it might not always be exactly the same because there's some latency between building an event and sending it. In addition, event sending could stop due to DAQ FIFO being almost full or DAQLink not being ready.

Units = clock cycles @ 160MHz. This indicates the maximum amount of time that event builder took to build and close the event. Note: this is mostly for debugging, most of the time it should be equal to 'End of event timeout'
Units = clock cycles @ 160MHz. This shows how long event builder took to build and close the last event. Note: this is mostly for debugging, but could be used to tune the 'end of event timeout'
contains the last 192+32 bits received from the VFAT and OH
Number of times this link didn't see the correct comma character at the correct time
Number of overflow occurences in the track tx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of underflow occurences in the track tx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of overflow occurences in the track rx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of underflow occurences in the track rx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of overflow occurences in the trigger link0 rx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of underflow occurences in the trigger link0 rx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of overflow occurences in the trigger link1 rx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of underflow occurences in the trigger link1 rx synchronization FIFO (should be 0, otherwise there's something wrong with clocks)
Number of not-in-table errors in the tracking rx link
Number of dispersion errors in the tracking rx link
Number of not-in-table errors in the trigger link0 rx
Number of dispersion errors in the trigger link0 rx
Number of not-in-table errors in the trigger link1 rx
Number of dispersion errors in the trigger link1 rx
Clock debug counter -- the lowest 16 bits are counting track/control RX clocks and the top 16 bits are counting the 160MHz TTC clocks
Counters related to the VFAT CRC values
Counter for each VFAT number of data packets with valid CRC
CRC counters for the tracking data for VFAT${VFAT_IDX}
write any value to the register to reset the counter Use mask to only allow writing to the first bit
Counter for each VFAT number of data packets with incorrect CRC
CRC counters for the tracking data for VFAT${VFAT_IDX}
write any value to the register to reset the counter Use mask to only allow writing to the first bit
Counters related to the OptoHybrid wishbone
Counters related to the OptoHybrid T1 signals
T1 signals received from the GLIB TTC decoder by way of the uTCA backplane (AMC13)
T1 signals generated by the OptoHybrid firmware
T1 signals recieved from an external source
T1 signals sent in loopback mode
T1 signals sent to the GEB (VFATs)
Counters related to the OptoHybrid optical links
Error counter on the tracking data optical link
Error counter on the trigger data optical link
Number of received data packets counter on the optical link
Control on the OptoHybrid related to the VFATs
Masks individual VFATs from sending tracking data packets
Allows to mask individual VFAT2s for SBits data readout

Selects the source of T1 signals sent to the GEB (3 bits [0,4]: 0: T1 from GLIB TTC decoder over backplane (AMC13) 1: T1 from OptoHybrid firmware 2: T1 from external source 3: Internal loopback on S-bits 4: Logical OR of all sources
Selects the S-bit source to loop back (5 bits)
Control on the OptoHybrid related to the clocking
Select the reference clock source (3 bits): 0: on board oscillator 1: GTX recovered clock 2: external clock
Control on the OptoHybrid related to the SBits sent out
Select the SBit sources to send out (30 bits, maximum 6 may be set high)
Throttle the triggers sent to the GEB
Returns the lock status of the FPGA clock PLL
Returns the lock status of the external clock PLL
Returns the lock status of the CDCE
Returns the lock status of the recovered clock (GTX)
Returns the lock status of the QPLL
Returns the lock status of the QPLL to FPGA clock PLL
T1 controller provided on the OptoHybrid

3 bits to select the mode: 0: Send N T1 commands of type type with an interval of interval BXs. 1: Send N packets composed of a Calpulse followed by an LV1A separated by delay BXs. 2: Send T1 commands according to a pattern defined by the sequence registers
4 bits to select the type of T1 signal (only for mode 0 and 1) 0: L1A 1: CalPulse 2: Resync 3: BC0
Number of repetitions to send (only for mode 0 and 1) default is 0 = infinite
How many BX between signals (only for mode 0 and 1) Minimum 3
Number of clock cycles between CalPulse and L1A (only for mode 1). Between 3 clock cycles and INTERVAL - 3 clock cycles
Define sequences of signals to generate (only for mod 2), 64 bit patterns for each signal
Status monitor for the T1 controller (4 bits): 0: nothing running 1: mode 1 running 2: mode 2 running 3: mode 3 running
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 0
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 1
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 2
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 3
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 4
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 5
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 6
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 7
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 8
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 9
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 10
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 11
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 12
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 13
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 14
Returns the value from the ADC for channel 15
Module to perform threshold and latency scans in the firmware
Control the onboard threshold/latency scan routine
Start the specified scan routine Will also empty the results FIFO from the previous scan
Select the scan mode (4 bits): 0: Threshold scan (per VFAT) 1: Threshold scan (per channel) 2: Lateny scan 3: S-curve scan (per channel)
Select which VFAT2 to scan (5 bits [0,23])
Select which channel to do a per channel threshold scan on (8 bits [0,255]) (only for per-channel threshold scan)
Minimum value of the register to scan from (8 bits [0,255]) Default: 0x0
Maximum value of the register to scan to (8 bits [0,255]) Default: 0xFF
How much to step the register value by each point (8 bits [0,255]) Default: 0x1
Number of triggers to collect at each scan point Default: 0 = 0xffffff

FIFO holding the scan results This register will return the data points collected by the scan using the following data format: 8 MSBits hold the threshold/latency value of the point 24 LSBits hold the number of events that have fired If no data is present, an error is returned.
Status monitor for the threshold/latency scan controller (2 bits): 0: nothing running 1: threshold scan running 2: channel threshold scan running 3: latency scan running 4: S-curve scan running
Control the onboard DAC scan routine
Start the specified scan routine Will also empty the results FIFO from the previous scan
Select the DAC to scan (4 bits): 0: IPreampIn 1: IPreampFeed 2: IPreampOut 3: IShaper 4: IShaperFeed 5: IComp 6: VThreshold1 7: VThreshold1 8: VCal 9: CalOut
Select which VFAT2 to scan (5 bits [0,23])
Minimum value of the register to scan from (8 bits [0,255]) Default: 0x0
Maximum value of the register to scan to (8 bits [0,255]) Default: 0xFF
How much to step the register value by each point (8 bits [0,255]) Default: 0x1
Number of triggers to collect at each scan point Default: 0 = 0xffffff

FIFO holding the scan results This register will return the data points collected by the scan using the following data format: 8 MSBits hold the DAC value of the point 24 LSBits hold the mean of the ADC values If no data is present, an error is returned.
Status monitor for the threshold/latency scan controller (1 bit): 0: nothing running 1: scanning a DAC
complete GEB address table, including: the individual VFAT I2C request module the broadcast VFAT I2C request module
Module to broadcast transactions to multiple VFATs
Which register request will be broadcast to all (non-masked) VFATs
VFAT control register 0 Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0xa8
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x50
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x96
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x96
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x64
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x78
8 least significant bits in the chip ID
8 most significant bits in the chip ID
Pointer to one of the extended registers Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Data to be written to the extended register pointed to by ExtRegPointer Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Programs the L1A latency, each bit is a single clock cycle (0-255 clock cycles, up to 6.4us) Hardwired sleep value 0x80 Software default value 0x80
Registers for the individual VFAT channels Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Determines the variable calibration voltage (between 0.877V and 1.074V) Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x64
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x1a
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Third control register Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Fourth control register Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
24 bit mask for which VFATs will/not receive the I2C register request broadcast 0 means associated VFAT will receive the request, 1 means associated VFAT will not receive the request

FIFO holding the responses from each un-masked VFAT This register will return the response of each individual request made to the VFAT2s: 8 MSBits are constant 0s 8 next bits hold the status of the transaction 8 next bits are the VFAT2 id (0 to 23) 8 LSBits hold response from the VFAT2 If no data is present, an error is returned.
VFAT registers controled by the GLIB user registers
VFAT control register 0 Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0xa8

Data to be written to the extended register pointed to by ExtRegPointer Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Programs the L1A latency, each bit is a single clock cycle (0-255 clock cycles, up to 6.4us) Hardwired sleep value 0x80 Software default value 0x80
Registers for the individual VFAT channels Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x00
Determines the variable calibration voltage (between 0.877V and 1.074V) Hardwired sleep value 0x00 Software default value 0x64

Legacy system registers (taken from GLIB system core). These should be removed once the software is made compatible with the new system registers.
GLIB firmware date (dd.mm.yy) and version number (x.y.z)
CDCE synchronization, transition from 0 to 1 needed to resync

configure the routing of the clocks on the xpoint2 switch if bit 0 is 0 and bit 1 is 0, the output takes input 1 as the source if bit 0 is 0 and bit 1 is 1, the output takes input 2 as the source if bit 0 is 1 and bit 1 is 0, the output takes input 3 as the source if bit 0 is 1 and bit 1 is 1, the output takes input 4 as the source

configure the routing of the clocks on the xpoint1 switch if bit 0 is 0 and bit 1 is 0, the output takes input 1 as the source if bit 0 is 0 and bit 1 is 1, the output takes input 2 as the source if bit 0 is 1 and bit 1 is 0, the output takes input 3 as the source if bit 0 is 1 and bit 1 is 1, the output takes input 4 as the source
SFP1 status, bit 1 Mod_abs, bit 2 RxLOS, bit 3 TxFault
SFP2 status, bit 1 Mod_abs, bit 2 RxLOS, bit 3 TxFault
SFP3 status, bit 1 Mod_abs, bit 2 RxLOS, bit 3 TxFault
SFP4 status, bit 1 Mod_abs, bit 2 RxLOS, bit 3 TxFault
state of the FPGA reset line, driven by the CPLD
state of the 6-bit bus between the FPGA and the CPLD
SRAM interface control and status registers, and banks 1 and 2
SPI interface: data from FPGA to clock synthesizer
SPI interface: data from FPGA to clock synthesizer
SPI interface: configuration (polarity, phase, frequency, etc.,
SPI interface: data from clock synthesizer to FPGA
I2C interface: configuration (bus select, frequency, etc., only in bench mode)
for FW version 5.3 and higher, enable is bit 15(0x8000) instead of bit 11(0x800)
for FW version 5.3 and higher, reserved bits are [14:13](0x6000) instead of bit 12(0x1000)
for FW version 5.3 and higher, bus select is [12:10](0x1c00) instead of just bit 10(0x400)
I2C interface: transaction parameters (slave address, drive to slave, etc., only in bench mode)
special feature of this register, clears automatically the upper 4 bits
16-bit operation mode, (PHY only) 0-> standard 8-bit mode, 1->16-bit mode
Byte to write to the I2C slave
I2C interface: transaction reply (status, data from drive, etc., only in bench mode
firmware version 5.3 and above has different values, as in the description
only in firmware versions less than 5.3
only in firmware versions 5.3 and up
ICAP memory space (seems to not work at the moment)
